title: Help/advice needed
body:
I'm new to the game, and I'm having a lot of trouble.
I tried to play the tutorial so that i could learn, but they are useless. They gave no instructions on what to do, and no matter what I did, i could not move my champion or even perform any actions.
I also tried to play a game, but the server kept on crashing and freezing, and kicking me out. as a result, i received a warning about abandoning games despite the fact i had no say in the matter.
Please, can anyone help me? How do you play this game? What do you have to do to perform even the simplest action?
I want to give the game a go, it was highly recommended to me by a friend, but so far, I've found it very disappointing. Please, any assistance would be appreciated.

replies.body:
>They gave no instructions on what to do, and no matter what I did, i could not move my champion or even perform any actions.

Please keep in mind that the tutorial is coded to prevent you from taking action until it has finished explaining to you the basic mechanics of movement in the game. Usually it's not noticeable because the explanation has a fancy cinematic camera pan to keep you distracted. If that camera pan is not happening, then it could be a glitched client. Firstly, make sure your locale is correctly selected, and that your computer also has this locale selected. Then, try repairing the client from the patcher (it's in the cog, I believe. If not, try the question mark. Both are at the top right).

>I also tried to play a game, but the server kept on crashing and freezing,

The server has been playing up of recent, but it wasn't so bad that it was constantly kicking out players, just a bit of lag. What ISP are you with?

Try updating your OS and any graphics drivers you may have. If none of these work, reply to this message.

when I tried, there was no cinematic camera panning or text or anything. it just focused on my champion and remained there unmoving or anything for 10 minutes.
no matter what I tried, nothing happened.

Thank you for trying to help, but I really don't know what you're talking about when you say 'locale' 'patcher' 'ISP'  'OS' or any other terms like that. Sorry, I'm not very technically savvy.

Ah, it's ok. I just took the terminology for granted.

"Locale" means what language/location your computer is supposedly in. For example, if your locale is Australia, Sydney, then your time would automatically be adjusted to [UTC+ 10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTC%C2%B100:00) and your language would be set to "English AU". There is a setting for this on your computer, usually labeled "Region" or "Locale". I'm sorry that I can't be specific, but it's different for each OS.

Which leads onto OS, which means operating system. In essence, what software runs on your computer to run other software. Examples are Windows 7, Mac Yosemite, Ubuntu, Windows 8, etc.

Your ISP is your internet service provider. When you connected to the internet, you needed to pay a company for that connection. That company is your ISP. Examples are Telstra, Internode, Optus, Vodafone, etc.

Patcher is a term specifically for League of Legends. It's the first window that opens up when you double-click the League of Legends icon. What the patcher does is download the latest updates for the game for you, and then "patches" them onto your existing game. It's useful for if something goes wrong with installation, as it should just fix it automatically. You can manually evoke this action by clicking "Repair".

If you're on Windows, please do the following:
1. Press Winkey+R. Type in "dxdiag" without quotations. Hit Enter.
2. Click on the "Display" tab at the top of the window that opens up.
3. Upload the information relayed on that tab. You can do this by either using the Snipping Tool to create an uploadable screenshot which you can attach to your reply, or you can just type up everything that appears. I mainly need to know what's under "Name:", "Main Driver:", "Current Display Mode:" and if there are any "Notes".

If you need any help with that, tell me your OS and I'll be able to get you more exact instructions.

Ok...
I'm in Adelaide, and the computer has Windows (That's all i know i'm afraid)
I have no idea who my ISP is.
I don't know which key is the Winkey, and I don't know how to use a snipping tool.

sorry I can't be more help.

Ok, Winkey refers to the key on your keyboard that has the Windows logo on it. It may also be known as the meta key, the super key, or the physical start button. The version of Windows you have should be written on the box your computer came in, if you brought the computer that could work straight out of the box (you didn't install the OS yourself, which explains why you wouldn't know what it is; a computer cannot function without an OS).

If you don't know who your ISP is, ask the person whom provides you with an internet connection (like your administrator or guardians). If you don't know who that is, well, that's just bad practice. You shouldn't be using something which you don't know the limitations of or origin of it. It's like drinking the water that falls out of the sky and not knowing what rain is.

The snipping tool is available in all recent versions of Windows. It can be accessed by searching for it from the start menu. To do that, open the start menu, click the text box, and type in "Snipping Tool". It should be the first result. The icon looks like a pair of scissors with two circles behind it. Make sure the mode it's on is "rectangle", and once you do that, it should turn your screen grey-ish. Draw a rectangle over the area you want by dragging from one corner to the opposite.

To check your locale (and OS too, if you still haven't found that yet), there's two things. First, go into your control panel (accessible from searching for it from the start menu). Click "System and Security", and then "System" (the big green text) to see what OS is currently running. This is different if you're on Windows XP, which I highly doubt. To check your locale, press back twice to get back to the control panel's homescreen. Then click "Clock, Language, and Region". Here, you can check "Change location" to see if the correct region (Australia) is selected, and "Date and Time" to make sure your clock is set up correctly. You should be using "(UTC+ 9:30) Adelaide" for your "Time Zone". Then, go to the "Internet Time" tab and sync your clock to any of the servers listed. If it's already set to automatically sync, then you can just leave it.

tl dr; Go to Windows Help and search these things. They can explain it with pictures.

Did you get dxdiag to show you what display settings are currently enabled?

You have the latest OS and a suitable graphics card. That shouldn't be the issue. Your monitor has a queer resolution, though. Are you able to change it to something more common, like 1600x900, 1980x1080 or 1280x720? All this can be done by seaching for "Display" from the control panel.

Do you have any firewalls/anti-viruses activated on your system?

I can try. though what shows up on screen seems to look alright in terms of details/visuals.

I think there may be some firewalls and anti-viruses. But I don't know what. My brother set up the computer for my parents (I use their computer when I visit them. can't use mine at home because my computer is so old i can't even get onto the net)

Whether a computer can connect to the internet or not is not dependent on how old it is. What it's dependent on is the environment it's running in and whether the appropriate equipment is available. All computers support dial-up.

If you aren't sure about how your computer is set up, then you probably shouldn't be the one trying to repair it. Try and get your brother to help you with it.

Unless you don't want them to know you play League on that computer.

Oh, by the way, even though you cannot get the tutorial up and running, can you at least opt to not play it? You can always see it later, if you wish. Can you set up a custom game and see if you can at least command your character to move (right-click anywhere on the map)?

My own computer is connected to the net, but it takes me over an hour to be able to be able connect, and even then the connection drops out ever 5 minutes. That's why I have league on my parents computer (better connection and newer faster computer)

I would prefer to try the tutorial since ive never played the game before, and I dont know the controls.
I have 'played' 2 games however.
The first by accident. In that it never left the loading screen, and I was later warned for leaving a match despite not doing anything.
The second I tried a custom game: just me and a bot. Just like in the tutorials I couldn't move or perfom any action. All I could do was watch for 30 minutes as I was killed 6 times and lost the match

>and I was later warned for leaving a match despite not doing anything.

Oh man, that's tough. **Really tough.** Leaverbuster is not meant to kick in until it's sure that it's not a technical issue, and to drop the bomb like that on a new player. They really need to adjust it.

>All I could do was watch for 30 minutes as I was killed 6 times and lost the match

I'm not comprehending this. If you set up a custom game, and find that you can't issue any commands, then there's no way you can actually die. Your champion would be on the fountain and constantly regening their health, not to mention the bots don't aggro that far. Could you be clear in what exactly you can and can't do? Because to die, you would have to move your champion off that platform.

Have you tried asking your brother to help you with this?

All I can really tell you is once the game started I found I couldnt do anything (move, etc). No matter what I clicked, or where I clicked, my character remained where it was. Then suddenly the screen went grey, my character was laying on the ground, and a notice saying I died appeared. Then everything seemed to 'reset'. A few minutes later it happened all over again (screen went grey, etc)

I havent asked him yet, but I dont l dont like my chances. Its not something he's interested in (the game), and in situations like that he tends not to be helpful

That reveals some things. It drastically reduces the chances of it being a local issue on your computer. That sounds like there's a problem with your connection.

[This page](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664) has a bunch of things suggested by Riot to try and help with these sorts of situations. I'll provide a brief synopsis of the most influential ones:

* Switch connection, for example connecting with a wire instead of wirelessly.
* Turn off your firewall/anti-virus before playing.
* Completely uninstall your firewall/anti-virus (but be sure to reinstall once you're done!)
* Use an alternate DNS (this one is a bit complicated, instructions below).
* Forward League's ports (even more complicated, if you want to try then tell me your modem's manufacturer).
* Turn off any VPN or proxies (if you don't know what these are, then you don't have to worry).

To change your DNS in Windows 8:
1. Press Winkey (start) and type in "Control Panel". Click "Control Panel".
2. Click "Network and Internet".
3. Click "Network and Sharing Center".
4. Click "Change adapter settings" on the left hand side of the window.
5. Identify which connection is the currently active one. Should be the one that doesn't have the cross on it. Right click that and go into "Properties".
6. In the window that appears, there will be a list in the centre of it. Scroll down that list to somewhere near the bottom and select (do not untick) "Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)"
7. Click "Use the following DNS server  addresses:" and then type in 8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4 into the preferred and alternate fields respectively.
8. Click "OK", "OK" and close the rest of the windows.
9. Press Winkey (start) again and type in "Command Prompt". Right click "Command Prompt" and then click "Run as Administrator..."
10. Type in (copy and paste does not work here) "ipconfig /flushdns" and then press Enter.
11. When it's done, restart your computer.

If that's still failing, check the quality of your connection through this site:
http://netalyzr.icsi.berkeley.edu/
It's an institute which has created this tool to assist people in diagnosing their internet connection. It requires Java to be installed and running on your system, as well as your browser having permission to use it. Usually, this means just clicking "Allow" to the prompt that comes up. If it doesn't, however, then that probably means you don't have Java installed. If that's the case, ask me. It's not the most straight-forward procedure.

Hopefully this will at least make what's going on a bit more clearer. Sorry for the wall of text, but making it shorter just won't work.

>and have wasted your time.

If something's not working, then it's never a waste of time trying to fix it.

For wireless v. wired connections, you must first establish what connection you already have. If you have a laptop, almost 100% of the time it's wireless due to the portable nature of it. Some older laptops will still have support for a wired connection but actively encourage you **not** to use it. The fastest way to check is by asking the person who set up the computer. If they say the computer uses "Wi-Fi" then it's wireless. If it's anything else, then it's probably wired. If it's wireless, try plugging in a network cable into the computer and connecting to the internet that way.

Almost all firewalls and anti-viruses function in a different way, so it's pretty much impossible to set up generic instructions on how to do it for each program. Your best bet would be to go to the help documentation that comes with your program. Older ones will provide this documentation with the disc cover, but the newer ones opt to have all their documentation online (usually found in the "Help" submenu).

To uninstall a firewall/anti-virus, however, you can use Window's Control Panel. Go into the Control Panel and then click "Uninstall programs". Find your firewall/anti-virus and click "Uninstall", then follow the on-screen instructions. Some might ask you if you want to retain your settings, in which case you do because you'll be reinstalling later on.

I can't really explain how to change your DNS in a more transparent manner. And port-forward is still pretty complicated. It's very much related to how much you know about your router.

Most internet cafes will sport a copy of League on their system. It might be really costly to use, however. That in combination of risking your password being stolen and not being able to save your configurations, I would not suggest it.

a possible connection problem? damn.

I am a bit worried though. Since the game is on my parent's computer, I'm kind of reluctant to change any settings or such. Not to mention I don't know how to do most of what you've suggested (Turning off or uninstalling firewalls/anti virus, changing from wireless to wire, etc)

(Sorry, I'm very basic when it comes to technology. I recently was forced to switch to a smart phone when my old one died, and I still don't know how to use it. The best way I can describe it is, I'm analogue in a digital world)

It sounds like i might have to give up trying to play League until I can find a computer/connection that can work (I don't even know if there's any cyber-cafes/game venues (?) about that I can visit).

I really want to thank you for your help. I appreciate that you've tried giving me some possible solutions and advice. I'm just sorry I'm not smart enough to put them into practice, and have wasted your time.
